articles.headline: Tourre’s Defense Rests Without Calling a Witness
articles.snippet: The defense team for Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader accused of defrauding investors in a mortgage deal six years ago, began its case at about 11:47 a.m. One minute later, it rested.
articles.abstract: The defense team for Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader accused of defrauding investors in a mortgage deal six years ago, began its case at about 11:47 a.m. One minute later, it rested.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | Lawyers for Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader accused of defrauding investors in a mortgage deal six years ago, rested their defense on Monday without calling any witnesses, a surprise move that now sets the stage for the closing of one of the most prominent cases from the financial crisis to go to trial.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A City Invokes Seizure Laws to Save Homes
articles.snippet: With recent gains in home prices doing little for some blighted neighborhoods, Richmond, Calif., is about to become the first city in the nation to try a novel way to stop foreclosures.
articles.abstract: With recent gains in home prices doing little for some blighted neighborhoods, Richmond, Calif., is about to become the first city in the nation to try a novel way to stop foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The power of eminent domain has traditionally worked against homeowners, who can be forced to sell their property to make way for a new highway or shopping mall. But now the working-class city of Richmond, Calif., hopes to use the same legal tool to help people stay right where they are.

articles.headline: Pivot TV Pitches to Young Viewers
articles.snippet: A channel for young people called Pivot, which will become available in 40 million homes on Thursday, aims for “entertainment that inspires and compels social change.”
articles.abstract: A channel for young people called Pivot, which will become available in 40 million homes on Thursday, aims for “entertainment that inspires and compels social change.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Evan Shapiro’s semester-long course on television management at New York University, he spends an hour on the topic “Building a Post-Network Channel from the Ground Up.” For the 19- and 20-year-old students — the fickle viewers that advertisers and programmers so desperately want to reach — the final assignment is to pitch some sort of TV innovation, be it a new way to schedule shows, a distribution strategy or even a brand-new network.

articles.headline: New Challenges for the Fixers of Boeing’s 787
articles.snippet: The costs and methods for repairing the carbon-composite jet are unclear, and the Dreamliner damaged by fire at Heathrow will be the first test of major work.
articles.abstract: The costs and methods for repairing the carbon-composite jet are unclear, and the Dreamliner damaged by fire at Heathrow will be the first test of major work.
articles.lead_paragraph: The thin plastic skin on Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner is an engineering marvel, a mix of carbon fibers and epoxy molded into large barrel-shaped sections that are then baked at up to 350 degrees in giant ovens.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Odd Fox News Interview Lifts Reza Aslan’s Biography on Jesus
articles.snippet: A Fox News interviewer awkwardly questioned the Muslim author on why he had written about Jesus, and sales of his book, “Zealot,” surged once the video caught fire online.
articles.abstract: A Fox News interviewer awkwardly questioned the Muslim author on why he had written about Jesus, and sales of his book, “Zealot,” surged once the video caught fire online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reza Aslan, the author of “Zealot,” a provocative new biography of Jesus, has found an inadvertent ally in generating book publicity: Fox News.

articles.headline: U.S. Balancing Act With Egypt Grows Trickier
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has prodded Egypt’s generals to restore a democratic government while trying not to jeopardize any future influence on the military or undermine security arrangements.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has prodded Egypt’s generals to restore a democratic government while trying not to jeopardize any future influence on the military or undermine security arrangements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In four weeks of quiet but intense diplomacy, the Obama administration has engaged in a balancing act, prodding Egypt’s generals to avoid violence and restore a democratic government while trying not to jeopardize any future influence on the military or undermine security arrangements that have been at the heart of a three-decade relationship.

articles.headline: Economic Slowdown Is Expected, but It’s Seen as Fleeting
articles.snippet: The performance of the economy in the second quarter is one of many guides to when the Fed will taper off its bond-buying.
articles.abstract: The performance of the economy in the second quarter is one of many guides to when the Fed will taper off its bond-buying.
articles.lead_paragraph: It can only get better from here — or at least that’s what economists hope.

articles.headline: Apps That Know What You Want, Before You Do
articles.snippet: Technology companies are rushing into predictive search, developing apps like Google Now that process digital clues to anticipate what users want to know.
articles.abstract: Technology companies are rushing into predictive search, developing apps like Google Now that process digital clues to anticipate what users want to know.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In Hollywood, there are umbrella holders. Outside corner offices, there are people who know exactly how much cream to pour in the boss’s coffee. In British castles, royals have their valets.

articles.headline: Morsi’s Visitors Leave a Mystery on Where He Is
articles.snippet: The European Union’s top foreign policy official was the most recent person to visit the deposed Egyptian president, who is being held in a secret location.
articles.abstract: The European Union’s top foreign policy official was the most recent person to visit the deposed Egyptian president, who is being held in a secret location.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mohamed Morsi, deposed as president by the Egyptian military on July 3, is in good health, a trickle of visitors allowed access to him and his aides in recent days has revealed. Where he is, however, remains a mystery that has enraged his family and supporters, and aggravated Egypt’s crisis.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: JPMorgan Looks to Pay to Settle U.S. Inquiries
articles.snippet: The payouts began on Tuesday when JPMorgan struck a $410 million settlement with the nation’s top energy regulator.
articles.abstract: The payouts began on Tuesday when JPMorgan struck a $410 million settlement with the nation’s top energy regulator.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:00 p.m. |  JPMorgan Chase is pulling out its checkbook to help mend frayed relationships with the government.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Manning Is Acquitted of Aiding the Enemy
articles.snippet: Pfc. Bradley Manning was convicted of multiple counts of violating the Espionage Act for leaking documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks, but was found not guilty of the more serious charge of “aiding the enemy.”
articles.abstract: Pfc. Bradley Manning was convicted of multiple counts of violating the Espionage Act for leaking documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks, but was found not guilty of the more serious charge of “aiding the enemy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — A military judge on Tuesday found Pfc. Bradley Manning not guilty of “aiding the enemy” for his release of hundreds of thousands of military and diplomatic documents to WikiLeaks for publication on the Internet, rejecting the government’s unprecedented effort to bring such a charge in a leak case.
